info.game_comments:
2001 Holiday Kids Week game 4.

(Cheryl: I'm Cheryl of the Clue Crew at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County.  Shhh!  Jeopardy!'s been bugged--next.)

(1, 1).clue: Dec. 17, 1903: These brothers make the first successful powered flight

(2, 1).clue: "We wish you a merry Christmas, we wish you a merry Christmas, we wish you a merry Christmas and" this

(3, 1).clue: Found worldwide this insect has legs adapted for jumping

(4, 1).clue: When microwaving a whole potato, do this to it so it doesn't explode

(5, 1).clue: Of Harvard, USC or Yale, the one that's not an Ivy League college

(6, 1).clue: A peck & a smooch are different names for this

(1, 2).clue: December 25th, 1776: This American general seen here leads an important surprise attack

(2, 2).clue: It's what we're to "deck the halls" with

(3, 2).clue: It's not a butterfly but this flyer seen here:

(4, 2).clue: If chives were chive talkin' they'd mention they were part of this veggie's family

(5, 2).clue: In a famous work by Herman Melville, Moby Dick is this kind of animal

(6, 2).clue: Now a symbol of love, the ancient Greeks thought it was the center of your intelligence

(1, 3).clue: Dec. 16, 1963: Zanzibar & Kenya become the 112th & 113th members of this world organization

(2, 3).clue: "On the third day of Christmas, my true love sent to me three" of these

(3, 3).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew with a creature on her arm.)  The emperor variety of this stinging critter is uh, making a move on me

(4, 3).clue: Garlic bulbs are broken up into segments called these for cooking

(5, 3).clue: Of apatosaurus, tyrannosaurus or thesaurus, the one that's not a dinosaur

(6, 3).clue: When the kids in "Peter Pan" are called this, it could be an endearment or just their last name

(1, 4).clue: Dec. 11, 1951:  Joe DiMaggio retires from pro baseball after 13 years playing for this New York team

(2, 4).clue: In German this traditional yuletide favorite is titled "O Tannenbaum"

(3, 4).clue: It's the religious predator seen here:

(4, 4).clue: An L.A. Times correction on March 29, 2001 reported that one of these it had shown as edible can be poisonous

(5, 4).clue: A king once ruled in what is now this U.S. state found in the Pacific Ocean

(6, 4).clue: An emotional celebration may include the "group" type of this embrace

(1, 5).clue: Dec. 18, 1787:  New Jersey becomes the third state to ratify this important U.S. document

(2, 5).clue: In 929 this "Good King" of song, who was actually a duke, was murdered by his wicked younger brother

(3, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew with a creature on his hand.) Similar to the centipede this segmented arthropod can probably count to a thousand all by itself

(4, 5).clue: All out of pumpkins?  You can substitute the butternut type of this in recipes

(5, 5).clue: Native to a region of Croatia it's the dog breed seen here:

(6, 5).clue: These first two lines of a lot of mushy poems mention the flowers seen here:
(6, 5).correct response: Roses are red, violets are blue

(1, 1).clue: Admiral Nelson's 1798 defeat of the French is a called the battle of this Egyptian river

(2, 1).clue: Sharing its name with a state, it's the only one of the Great Lakes entirely within the U.S.

(3, 1).clue: Naresh lives in India, so his e-mail address includes this 2-letter country code

(4, 1).clue: In "The Muppet Christmas Carol" Michael Caine plays this miserly character

(5, 1).clue: Members of the House of Representatives serve terms of this many years

(6, 1).clue: It can be a lump of gold or a bite-size piece of chicken

(2, 2).clue: The Gulf of Mexico is actually an arm of this second-largest ocean

(3, 2).clue: For dessert Naresh loves barfi, a type of this often chocolate candy that we serve hot on sundaes

(4, 2).clue: In "Muppet Treasure Island", this character plays Benjamina Gunn, queen of the island's warthogs

(5, 2).clue: The George C. Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama is run by this U.S. agency

(6, 2).clue: This land is the setting for a series of books beginning with "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe"

(2, 3).clue: This nearly 4,000-mile-long river begins high in the Andes Mountains

(4, 3).clue: The gang hope to sing & dance on Broadway when "The Muppets Take" this title place

(5, 3).clue: When a bill reaches the President's desk, he may approve & sign it, do nothing, or do this

(6, 3).clue: This large city in Africa is Kenya's capital

(1, 4).clue: On Oct. 14, 1066 Anglo-Saxon King Harold II was killed at the Battle of Hastings against this "Conqueror"

(2, 4).clue: Iraq & Kuwait lie at the northern end of this gulf where a war broke out in 1991

(3, 4).clue: In Calcutta Naresh once saw Mother Teresa, one of these religious women who helped the poor

(4, 4).clue: This Muppet goes to Grouchland in search of his lost fuzzy blue blanket

(5, 4).clue: Donald Rumsfeld has served as Secretary of this twice: once under Gerald Ford & now under George W. Bush

(6, 4).clue: It's the central part of an atom, or part of the head of a comet

(1, 5).clue: 8 Minutemen were killed by the British before they retreated in this first battle of the American Revolution

(2, 5).clue: This "stately" river forms the boundary between New York & Pennsylvania

(3, 5).clue: Naresh practices this, the main religion of India, & tells me all about karma & reincarnation

(4, 5).clue: Gonzo receives extra terrestrial messages from his breakfast cereal in this film

(5, 5).clue: This document served as our basic charter of government from 1781 until the Constitution in 1789

(6, 5).clue: In a work of fiction, it's the term for the person who tells the story

(0, 0).clue: Appropriately, the mayflower is the official flower of this state
